data.name: Present Simple
rules: In the third person singular, the verb always ends in '-s'
For negative and interrogative forms, use 'does/do'
examples: She does not run so fast
We catch the bus every morning
You walk for two hundred meters, then you turn left
New York is a large city
He goes to school every morning
We do not think about that
He drinks a lot on parties

data.name: Present Continuous
whenToUse: Actions happening at the moment of speaking
examples: We are going to the beach
More and more people are becoming vegetarian
Are you still working for the same company?
I am not going to my home
Are you going to the office?

data.name: Present Perfect
whenToUse: When the precise time of action is not important or not know
An action or situation that started in the past and continues in the present
rules: Have/has + irregular verb: third column of irregular verbs
examples: I have never fallen down the stairs
I have lived in Barcelona since 1982
Have you played the piano since you were a child?
We have visited Portugal several times
We have had the same car for ten years
It has happened several times already
I've worked here for six months
I haven't gone to the cinema for a long time
I have just finished my work
I have been to London recently

data.name: Present Perfect Continuous
examples: I've heard a lot about you recently
They have been travelling since last October
She has been cooking since last night
I have been waiting for you for three hours
He has not been playing handball

data.name: Past Continuous
examples: I was playing with my best friend

data.name: Past Perfect Continuous
examples: We had been waiting for ages before the bus finally arrived

data.name: Future Simple
examples: I will help you in a few minutes
She is going to the beach tomorrow
